concern: 4th semester at a CC, and now I'm getting worried. I'm doing "okay" on exams now. I'm taking more "advanced" classes now, and it's getting harder to wing it. I remember cramming everything the night before, and I passed with either As or Bs. Now I need to start studying the day I learn the material, but I just can't get to the habit of doing so. Any tips for this?

dialogue_total.statement: It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and stressed out. That's a lot to handle. I'm here to listen and help you work through this. Can you tell me more about what's been going on?

I've been finding it tough to adjust to the demands of my advanced classes, which is making me anxious about my study habits. It's hard for me to start studying right away instead of waiting until the last minute, and I'm not sure how to build that routine.

That sounds really challenging, especially with the added pressure of advanced classes. It's understandable that you're feeling anxious and having trouble with procrastination. What have you tried so far to build a better study routine?

I've tried setting up a daily study schedule on my phone, but I often end up ignoring it and procrastinating. I've also attempted to review notes right after class a few times, yet I quickly fall back into my old habit of cramming.

It can be tough to stick to a new routine, especially when old habits are so ingrained. But it's great that you're trying different strategies! It sounds like you're motivated to change, which is a really important first step. Let's explore some other ways you could build that study routine. Have you considered finding a study buddy or accountability partner to help you stay on track?
I haven't really considered finding a study buddy yet, as I've been trying to handle this on my own. It might help with staying accountable and breaking my procrastination habit, though.

It's great that you're open to the idea of a study buddy. Sometimes, having someone to share the journey with can make it easier to stay on track and motivate each other. Is there anyone in your classes who you think might be a good study partner?

I know a couple of classmates who seem dedicated and organized in our advanced classes, so one of them might make a good study partner to help me build better habits. I'm a bit nervous about reaching out, but I think it could motivate me to study more consistently right from the start.

That's a great idea! Reaching out can be intimidating, but it's worth it if it helps you build better habits. How about setting a goal to talk to one of them by the end of the week and see if they'd be interested in being your study partner?

I think setting that goal makes senseit could help me stay accountable and start building the habit of studying right away. I'll aim to reach out to one classmate by the end of the week and see if they're interested.

It's encouraging to see your willingness to try new strategies, like finding a study partner, to help you build better study habits and overcome procrastination. Reaching out to a dedicated classmate by the end of the week is a great first step toward achieving your goal. Remember that making progress is a journey, and each step forward brings you closer to success. Keep up the good work, and feel free to reach out again if you need further support or guidance.
Thanks for the encouragement I'll reach out to a classmate by the end of the week to help me build consistent study habits right from the start.
